DataElement.preferredName: Uveal Melanoma Extravascular Matrix Pattern Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the kind of extravascular matrix pattern for the uveal melanoma tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Uveal Melanoma Extravascular Matrix Patterns Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A melanoma derived from melanocytes of the uveal tract.  It is the most common primary intraocular tumor in the United States and Western Europe.  Similar to melanoma of the skin, it is rare in Africa and Asia.  Diagnostic procedures include ophthalmoscopic exam, fluorescein angiography and ultrasound.  Treatment includes: surgical excision of the eye, iridocyclectomy and tumor resection.  Recent treatments also include radiotherapy or photo coagulation.  Classification of uveal melanomas recognizes four cell types within these tumors: epithelioid, intermediate, mixed cell, and spindle cell types.  The spindle cell type uveal melanomas are further sub-classified as spindle cell type A and spindle cell type B._A microscopic finding indicating the presence of patterns formed by malignant cells outside the blood vessel circulation in uveal melanoma.  The patterns are detectable using PAS stain without counterstaining with hematoxylin.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A melanoma derived from melanocytes of the uveal tract.  It is the most common primary intraocular tumor in the United States and Western Europe.  Similar to melanoma of the skin, it is rare in Africa and Asia.  Diagnostic procedures include ophthalmoscopic exam, fluorescein angiography and ultrasound.  Treatment includes: surgical excision of the eye, iridocyclectomy and tumor resection.  Recent treatments also include radiotherapy or photo coagulation.  Classification of uveal melanomas recognizes four cell types within these tumors: epithelioid, intermediate, mixed cell, and spindle cell types.  The spindle cell type uveal melanomas are further sub-classified as spindle cell type A and spindle cell type B.

Concepts.definition: A melanoma derived from melanocytes of the uveal tract.  It is the most common primary intraocular tumor in the United States and Western Europe.  Similar to melanoma of the skin, it is rare in Africa and Asia.  Diagnostic procedures include ophthalmoscopic exam, fluorescein angiography and ultrasound.  Treatment includes: surgical excision of the eye, iridocyclectomy and tumor resection.  Recent treatments also include radiotherapy or photo coagulation.  Classification of uveal melanomas recognizes four cell types within these tumors: epithelioid, intermediate, mixed cell, and spindle cell types.  The spindle cell type uveal melanomas are further sub-classified as spindle cell type A and spindle cell type B.

Property.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of patterns formed by malignant cells outside the blood vessel circulation in uveal melanoma.  The patterns are detectable using PAS stain without counterstaining with hematoxylin.

Concepts.definition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence of patterns formed by malignant cells outside the blood vessel circulation in uveal melanoma.  The patterns are detectable using PAS stain without counterstaining with hematoxylin.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

Hard, involved or complicated, elaborate, having many parts.

A microscopic finding indicating the presence of patterns formed by malignant cells outside the blood vessel circulation in uveal melanoma.  The patterns are detectable using PAS stain without counterstaining with hematoxylin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence or absence of extravascular matrix loops in uveal melanoma.

Concepts.definition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence or absence of extravascular matrix loops in uveal melanoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence or absence of loops forming networks in uveal melanoma.

Concepts.definition: A microscopic finding indicating the presence or absence of loops forming networks in uveal melanoma.
